admreg: Middle East and North Africa,Middle East and North Africa

0.cdata!: Maroc - Premier projet de formation professionnelle

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Vocational
            Training Project in Morocco were to address key sector
            issues by contributing to expanding vocational training
            capacity consistent with future needs for skilled labor
            force, improving coordination of vocational training,
            contributing to the financial viability of the main public
            vocational training institution and helping to develop
            appropriate future training activities. The project was to
            also help improve project selection and preparation in the
            public sector. The loan beneficiaries were: (i) the office
            for vocational training and employment promotion (OFPPT) for
            the construction and equipment of 22 new Vocational Training
            Centers (VTC) as well as for other studies related to
            -training of instructors and curricula development: (ii) the
            vocational and staff training administration (AFPFC) for the
            studies dealing with coordination and financing of
            vocational training and development of future training
            activities; and (iii) the Ministry of planning for a
            component aiming at improving project selection and
            preparation in the public sector. The main project objective
            of expansion of the vocational training capacity was met.
            The enrollment capacity increased by 6,630 instead of 4,775
            planned, and the additional number of graduates per year to
            3,000 instead of 2,200. However, the project's impact
            has not been as positive as expected. The vocational
            training graduates are currently experiencing serious
            difficulties in finding employment due to a substantial
            mismatch between their number and the economy's ability
            to absorb them, as well as between the diplomas they hold
            and the skills that enterprises need. This result is due to
            a lack of relevance of training as well as to a slower
            employment creation than anticipated in the project.
